Mohan Nataraj is a professional Computer Scientist & Pure Mathematician from the Silicon Valley of India – Bangalore with professional experience of two or more years working in start up in the Bay Area. My research interests include distribution of prime number, continuous and discrete topology (graph theory), abstract algebra, statistics and any programmable matter. As a part of my hobby I perform calisthenics as well as into professional boxing which is a great way to stimulate my mind and keep my body active. I also love snow boarding and hiking, and strum my guitar chords (yet learning the switch - finger’s hurt :( ) apart from physical activities you can notice my innate passion towards mathematics, philosophy and technology.
For more follow my posts here, I do refrain from social media.
 Feel free to contact me for casual conversation or opinions regarding my posts - always great to know your view and have an good conversation via mail.
 P.S. Note : I believe in Karma - a basic principal of life to live by. 
 Currently accepted into Carleton University - Pure Mathematics

This is pretty cool talk by Charles Stross, given at Chaos Computer Club congression this talk reflects my opinion or views on current world of corporates, startups, artificial intelligence (referred by speaker as corporate AI and computerized AI) and one ridiculed CEO or lets say more than one [:P]. You can also find reason’s on why I quit facebook or hated it in the first place.
The talk starts by saying on how prediction 3 centuries back or even a century back was possible to do accurately. Which infact reminds me of what my astrologer threw at me when I asked him where I will exactly be in 5 years [:D], yep a typical South Indian boy. Further the speaker talks about Artificial Intelligence singularity (computerized), infact you can giggle on when the speaker says @ 7:30 “if we created an AI equivalent of human mind it would be sitting on a couch and watching super bowl all day”, I’m sure to say this is one of the least obnoxious way anyone can put it knowing what we human’s are capable of doing or the way we live in 21st century.
To continue on the speaker says “AI as self optimizing tool which defy human comprehension”, which is quite absolutely right, and while the comparison of airplane to seagull makes us want to giggle, we can also wonder if our education system & professor’s are doing good enough to produce skillful people or are we just about the grades ?
 Well, continuing on the next statement that caught my attention when the speaker says “history is useful for so much more than that” funny on how forget our past in speaker’s words “our personal memory don’t span very long at all”, haha! in fact, every 5 year’s we vote. [:D]
The speaker further goes on to talk about paper clip maximizer theory of artificial intelligence and one of the CEO that supports it. Which to me seems funny on how people see things especially some the most renowned CEO’s. Just WOW!!! The speakers quirky comments are quite joyful and his correlation to corporations and governmental organization are so damn true.
While I can go on for quite a bit about this talk. I would like to keep the writing short and let you watch the video. This is more of an opinionated talk and is very entertaining. The speaker not so surprisingly also talks about the corporations like Facebook - its role in the society and developers building app’s that gets people addicted to them.
The speaker Charles Stross quite greatly articulates my views and reasons why I’m not on facebook and as well don’t own a smart phone anymore. It’s been almost a year and yep I am “that 90’s kid” it’s been great spending more time improving myself than being socially obsessed.
I hope you enjoy this video and get alot to learn. You have any comments, opinions or anything to discuss or want to know you can comment below or mail me.

Whilst “Bridges” are built to span through obstacles, the preceding statement was quite erring in the city of Königsberg in Prussia (now Kaliningrad, Russia) during the 18th century. Here we talk about the inception of Graph Theory, it’s application to the real world problems and a famous puzzle asked during my childhood. The blog also contain a pretty good talk given by a math student below in Chaos Computer Club congression.
During the 18th century in the city of Königsberg the land masses were connected by seven bridges. The problem or challenge in the city was to walk or traverse through the seven bridges only once, i.e; to walk atmost only once on all the bridges. While the challenge was talk of the town during the period, we show on how Leonhard Euler approached the problem that actually gave rise to “Graph Theory”.
 left to right city of Königsberg converted into graph (graph theory)   The right most part of the image shows on how the land masses and bridges are converted into graph theoretic notation. The land masses are represented by a circle or commonly called “Node or Vertex” and the line connecting two nodes is called an “Edge”. An edge commonly defines a relationship between two nodes and they always connect two nodes. The last term to know is degree of a node which is actually the number of edges or lines incident on a node or vertex. Now since we got the basics of Graph Theory before diving into Euler’s solution I would like share the childhood puzzle I was talking about.
While in the 90’s and early 2000’s Bangalore was absolutely a great time to grow and have fun (name it sport, education to being a cool kid). One of the famous puzzle or the challenge thrown at us was to draw the below image such that without lifting your pen or pencil and most importantly you cannot pass over the line already drawn i.e; you cannot pass a line twice.
 figure to draw (familiar??)   While the above can be converted into graph theoretical notation just as how Leonhard Euler did it. Well just so, we can convert it by drawing circle or vertices or nodes at the four corners of the square and consider the line joining them as edges (curved lines are also edges). Now if you have tried solving the above you know that it is not possible to complete the following diagram, but almost possible well you may just miss one edge out of 10 (try). The explanation here is quite easy, I shall let you think with a hint “degree of vertex” well I hope that you paid attention to that term above to be more precise atleast two vertices or nodes or circles should have what number of degree’s (odd or even)? Hmmm!! Well did that just reveal the answer, hope not!!. But hey, just so you did not get the above story that’s absolutely fine see the video below :
    I hope you got it now, oh well there is always something about old white men and being genius got to blame Einstein. [:P] For more entertainment and want to know more about graph theory and video games as “we cool kids” love playing PC games. Here is a video from Chaos Computer Club
 The above video does have some very cool content if you are into topology, just to put it across in simple terms imagine “when you get your wife so angry that she would squeeze a donut in her hand so hard that it turns into a sphere”, hmmm!!! must say now “that’s not so pretty transformation huh??” Well if your a mathematician like me and your concerned with “Topology” I bet you would enjoy it as much as otherwise. :D
The real world application of graph theory is quite immense due to its simplicity, it ranges from waking across the 18th century bridges to current navigation technology, yep that’s right google maps does use it. You can also use it for scheduling airplanes, project management, production management and hey what’s more important than scheduling your life ?
Wanna know more feel free to comment or hit me up. I’m always looking forward to help you and my philosophy to share knowledge, it’s absolutely free, just get me coffee & donut :P.
